poem:
Marathon Man

In old skin, he dances  
over a worn ribbon of earth,  
the whisper of youth in each step,  
miles unfolding like petals,  
a hymn toward the horizon.  
At mile twenty, God ambles near,  
a shadow in lockstep,  
past eyes softened by sun,  
flesh etched with years,  
running the last six,  
beyond time's reach.
